image.altText: A globe centred on Australia showing sea surface temperature patterns in red and blue with a time scale labelled July 2023

items.synopsis: It’s the phenomenon behind some of Australia’s hottest, driest years, and climate change could be making it more extreme. Here’s why that doesn’t guarantee catastrophe this year — or in the future.

title.children: An El Niño could be declared as early as next week: This is what it looks like when it forms

image.altText: Catherine King stands at lecturn in front of airport signage

items.synopsis: Catherine King says the 2020 incident was one factor in her decision to reject Qatar's application to increase its flights to major Australian airports, but that no single issue swayed her one way or the other.

title.children: Transport minister says Doha strip search was 'context' for Qatar rejection

image.altText: A woman in a yellow jacket, a woman in a navy jacket sit on a green bench seat while a man stands and shouts

items.synopsis: The heated discussion over why Qatar Airways' bid to increase flights to Australia was rejected has left the government juggling excess political baggage, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: Just 11 seconds of answers preceded the third question on Qatar saga — and then all hell broke lose

image.altText: a small shark out of water

items.synopsis: Three sailors attempting a round-the-world voyage have been rescued after their boat was attacked off the coast of Cairns and began to sink. It's suspected their craft was set upon by cookiecutter sharks.

title.children: How a 40-centimetre shark brought a catamaran's round-the-world voyage to a halt

image.altText: People speaking to media and holding Voice for Victims signs.

items.synopsis: Hundreds marched on Brisbane Parliament House last month to demand tougher sentences for young offenders, as well as an independent advisory for victims of crime.

title.children: Pledge for Queensland victims of crime advisory group welcomed, but 'proof will be in the detail'

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Alan Joyce reportedly jets off with a substantial amount of cash and Qantas shares in his portfolio — but valid questions are being asked about whether he is entitled to all of it.

title.children: Alan Joyce leaves Qantas with millions in the bank, but his final scandal as CEO has slashed his last payout

image.altText: A dam and rolling green hills.

items.synopsis: Researchers identify thousands of locations for potential micro-pumped-hydro energy storage across rural Australia, using pre-existing farm dams and rivers.

title.children: Australia is pockmarked with small dams. With a little tweak, many could be turned into 'batteries'

image.altText: two womensmiling into the camera with a wall of art behind them

items.synopsis: Almost $40 million will be invested in eating disorder services in Queensland after demand for treatment spikes during the pandemic.

title.children: Lisa first came to an eating disorder service aged 16, as a patient. Now she works there

image.altText: Forecast chart showing blue over Great Australian Bight and SA, polar air mass heading for country's south-east

items.synopsis: It was a sunny start to the week but from today a polar air mass will sweep over south-east Australia, causing temperatures to plummet by as much as 15 degrees Celsius in 24 hours.

title.children: Hail, snow and gales to replace spring heat in a battle of the seasons

image.altText: Natalie Sinclair sitting at a table, reaching towards bottles of Hysone and Hydrocortisone.

items.synopsis: The drug Natalie Sinclair takes to keep her alive is among hundreds of medications that have been in short supply in Australia, but advocates fear stockholding laws for suppliers are having little impact on the ground.

title.children: 'Pretty terrifying': Advocates say medicine shortages still an issue, despite stockholding rules

image.altText: A Brisbane AFL ruckman bends down and scoops the ball ready to handball to a teammate as defenders watch.

items.synopsis: With the AFL finals set to begin, Andrew McGarry runs the rule over the eight contenders and analyses their strengths as well as the weaknesses that may stand in the way of a premiership win.

title.children: Why each team can — and can't — win the AFL flag in 2023

image.altText: A black and white photo of a woman outdoors.

items.synopsis: For three months, this Swiss adventurer walked alone for 1,500 kilometres through parts of the Nullarbor, Great Victoria Desert and Gibson Desert. She says Australia is now "in her blood".

title.children: While trekking in remote Australia, Sarah didn't speak for six weeks. She says it is 'magical'

image.altText: Aung San Suu Ky looks intensely into the camera at a conference.

items.synopsis: The son of Myanmar's detained former leader Aung San Suu Kyi says she is being refused urgent medical care despite her ill health.

title.children: Myanmar's ailing former leader Aung San Suu Kyi being denied medical care in prison, son says

image.altText: the front of a house and carport, with the ocean seen behind it

items.synopsis: The rise of short-term holiday rentals like Airbnb and Stayz have changed the way we travel, but they've also faced backlash over concerns they're driving rents up and exacerbating housing shortages in cities around the world.

title.children: How much are short-term rentals really impacting Australia's housing crisis?

image.altText: A submarine at the surface with morning sun on its right flank, the ocean stretches behind it

items.synopsis: As some Republicans raise concerns about the deal to supply American subs to Australia, a US Senate committee hears China's recent behaviour means "time is of the essence" in the trilateral AUKUS pact.

title.children: 'This is a critical moment': China's behaviour towards Australia makes AUKUS more urgent, US senator warns

image.altText: A smiling, dark-haired man leans on a trailer full of oranges in a citrus orchard.

items.synopsis: There are fears that short-term contracts and low prices for Valencia oranges could force some growers out of the industry.

title.children: Orange industry in Australia shrinking to the point of collapse as short-term contracts, lower prices hit growers

image.altText: Two Matildas players celebrate a goal during the FIFA Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: Sam Kerr earns another nomination for football's highest individual honour, while Matildas teammate Hayley Raso is recognised following her superb Women's World Cup campaign.

title.children: Matildas stars Sam Kerr and Hayley Raso in contention for prestigious Ballon d'Or

image.altText: A man with a shaved head wearing a t-shirt with "cancel me" written on it holds a microphone

items.synopsis: NSW sports minister says a whole sport can't be tarnished by "one or two people" after comments by controversial mix martial arts fighter Sean Strickland ahead of the tax-payer funded event.

title.children: UFC fighter makes sexist comments at press conference ahead of Sydney bout

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

items.synopsis: National Court prosecutors confirm Jenni Hermoso has filed a formal complaint about suspended Spanish soccer boss Luis Rubiales's decision to kiss her after last month's World Cup final in Sydney.

title.children: Spanish soccer star Hermoso files legal complaint over World Cup kiss

image.altText: An older man wearing a blue suit and tie and glasses sits in a room with a portrait of Australia's Parliament House behind him.

items.synopsis: Outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe will give his final public speech before handing over to Michele Bullock next week, while Wall Street fell after economic data prompted concerns interest rates will stay higher for longer. Follow live.

title.children: Philip Lowe to give final speech as RBA governor, ASIC sues PayPal Australia, Wall Street falls on interest rate fears

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Catherine King has also just spoken to AM host Sabra Lane, who asked the transport minister whether she met with ex-Qantas CEO Alan Joyce in the immediate period before she rejected Qatar Airways' bid for more flights. Here's some of the conversation: Sabra Lane: Did you meet or talk with Alan Joyce or any other Qantas representative before making this decision? Catherine King: I certainly routinely meet with the CEOs of all of the airlines. And of course, that would include Alan Joyce, so I routinely meet with all of the CEOs of the airlines, airports, peak bodies. SL: I'm sorry, it's a pretty simple question. Did you meet with Alan Joyce before making this decision? CK: I would have certainly met, you know, I have been a minister for 15 months, I would certainly in that 15 months have met with the CEO of all of the airlines, including the former CEO of Qantas. But can I say, from the best of my recollection, when it comes to this matter in particular, I received more lobbying on behalf of Qatar, both from Virgin, but also into my office from a third party than I did from Qantas on this issue. SL: In the immediate period before you made this decision, did you meet with Alan Joyce? CK: I'd have to go back and check, but I always meet with CEOs of airlines when they ask to do so. But can I absolutely make it very clear, the discussions that Qantas had with me and my office have on the whole been about same job, same pay, not about this decision. SL: Surely though, you would remember a conversation like this? CK: I don't remember a conversation like this, but I can't be 100% sure they didn't have a conversation with someone in my office or someone in my department. So I am being careful to let you know very clearly that by the best of my recollection, where I was lobbied about this issue was on the whole on behalf of Qatar, and Qantas discussions that I had, as I said in the parliament yesterday, were primarily about same job, same pay. I know that my department as is proper processes, undertook consultation with industry about this issue. And I was well aware of all of the stakeholder views in relation to this decision when I made it.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'I'd have to go back and check': King unable to say if she met with Alan Joyce before Qatar decision

children.content: Catherine King
has also just spoken to
AM host Sabra Lane
, who asked the transport minister whether she met with
ex-Qantas CEO Alan Joyce
in the immediate period before she rejected Qatar Airways' bid for more flights.
Here's some of the conversation:
Sabra Lane:
Did you meet or talk with Alan Joyce or any other Qantas representative before making this decision?
Catherine King:
I certainly routinely meet with the CEOs of all of the airlines. And of course, that would include Alan Joyce, so I routinely meet with all of the CEOs of the airlines, airports, peak bodies.
SL:
I'm sorry, it's a pretty simple question. Did you meet with Alan Joyce before making this decision?
CK:

I would have certainly met, you know, I have been a minister for 15 months, I would certainly in that 15 months have met with the CEO of all of the airlines, including the former CEO of Qantas. But can I say, from the best of my recollection, when it comes to this matter in particular, I received more lobbying on behalf of Qatar, both from Virgin, but also into my office from a third party than I did from Qantas on this issue.
SL:
In the immediate period before you made this decision, did you meet with Alan Joyce?
CK:

I'd have to go back and check, but I always meet with CEOs of airlines when they ask to do so. But can I absolutely make it very clear, the discussions that Qantas had with me and my office have on the whole been about same job, same pay, not about this decision.
SL:
Surely though, you would remember a conversation like this?
CK:

I don't remember a conversation like this, but I can't be 100% sure they didn't have a conversation with someone in my office or someone in my department. So I am being careful to let you know very clearly that by the best of my recollection, where I was lobbied about this issue was on the whole on behalf of Qatar, and Qantas discussions that I had, as I said in the parliament yesterday, were primarily about same job, same pay. I know that my department as is proper processes, undertook consultation with industry about this issue. And I was well aware of all of the stakeholder views in relation to this decision when I made it.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Transport Minister Catherine King is standing by her decision to reject a request from Qatar Airways to increase its flights into Australia, insisting it was in the national interest. Qantas lobbied the government against the decision, but Virgin and Qatar put reasons to the government about why it should go ahead. Meanwhile, five Australian women onboard a Qatar flight in 20-20 — who were forced to undergo invasive body examinations — encouraged the Ms King not to approve the flights. Yesterday it was confirmed Ms King sent a letter to the women involved in the incident the same day she denied Qatar's request. At a press conference this morning, she maintains the decision was in the national interest — but didn't expand on what "national interest" means. "As I've said repeatedly, I made this decision in the national interest, and there is no one factor that I will point to that swayed my decision one way or the other," she said. "In making this decision, I did have the national interest — not commercial interests — at play when I was making that decision. "I don't think that it helps for me to point to any one factor. We make decisions in the national interest all of the time."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Transport minister stands by decision to reject Qatar Airways' flight request

children.content: Transport Minister Catherine King
is standing by her decision to reject a request from Qatar Airways to increase its flights into Australia, insisting it was in the national interest.
Qantas lobbied the government against the decision, but Virgin and Qatar put reasons to the government about why it should go ahead.
Meanwhile, five Australian women onboard a Qatar flight in 20-20 — who were forced to undergo invasive body examinations — encouraged the Ms King not to approve the flights.
Yesterday it was confirmed Ms King sent a letter to the women involved in the incident the same day she denied Qatar's request.
At a press conference this morning, she
maintains the decision was in the national interest
— but didn't expand on what "national interest" means.
"As I've said repeatedly, I made this decision in the national interest, and
there is no one factor that I will point to that swayed my decision
one way or the other," she said.
"In making this decision, I did have the national interest — not commercial interests — at play when I was making that decision.
"I don't think that it helps for me to point to any one factor. We make decisions in the national interest all of the time."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ASIC, the Australian financial regulator, has launched legal action against PayPal Australia over allegedly unfair business contract terms. The proceedings allege PayPal Australia's contracts with small business customers contained an "unfair" term that gave business account holders 60 days to notify PayPal of any errors or discrepancies in fees they had been charged, or accept them as accurate. "ASIC alleges the term is unfair because the effect of the term is to permit PayPal to retain fees it has overcharged or wrongly charged if the small business does not notify PayPal of the error within 60 days of the fee appearing in its account statement," the watchdog's statement said. ASIC's deputy chair Sarah Court said the legal action was about protecting the interests of small businesses. "We allege this term is unfair because it allows PayPal to escape the consequences of its own errors in overcharging small businesses, and places additional burdens on small businesses to detect and correct charging errors," she said. PayPal Australia has been contacted for comment.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Financial regulator sues PayPal Australia for alleged 'unfair' contract term

business account holders 60 days to notify PayPal of any errors or discrepancies in fees they had been charged, or accept them as accurate
"ASIC alleges the term is unfair because
the effect of the term is to permit PayPal to retain fees it has overcharged or wrongly charged
if the small business does not notify PayPal of the error within 60 days of the fee appearing in its account statement," the watchdog's statement said.
ASIC's deputy chair Sarah Court
said the legal action was about
protecting the interests of small businesses
"We allege this term is unfair because it
allows PayPal to escape the consequences of its own errors
in overcharging small businesses, and places
additional burdens on small businesses
to detect and correct charging errors," she said.
PayPal Australia has been contacted for comment.

image.altText: A woman cutting flowers off a bush of Geraldton wax.

image.altText: An historic paddle wheeler emerges from the brown water of the Thomson River, with salvage crews on pontoons and machinery.

image.altText: a man smiling sitting next to a woman wearing a wedding dress

title.children: Man charged over Sydney paramedic murder allegedly assaulted woman day before

image.altText: A film photograph of a young woman wearing a RAAF uniform and smiling.
